Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary

USEPA 40 CFR Part 68

Subpart G 



Introduction



The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations 40 CFR Part 68, require facilities that have a regulated substance above the listed threshold quantities to develop a formal Risk Management Program. The Sanitary District of Michigan City (SDMC) maintains quantities of chlorine and sulfur dioxide above the RMP threshold quantity of 2,500 and 5,000 pounds, respectively, and as such, is subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68. A hazard review was completed to determine that RMP program level 3 is applicable to SDMC's chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems. 



The information presented in this section is intended to describe the elements of SDMC's Risk Management Program. The format of the section corresponds to the executive summary data elements as described in 40 CFR Part 68 Executive Summary Section. 



Executive Summary Data Elements

According to EPA guidance the executive summary must include a brief description of the facility's Risk Management Program. The following sections list each of the required executive summary data elements by rule citation. In accordance with EPA guidance, the Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) is not covered in the executive summary. 



68.155(a) Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies



The Sanitary District of Michigan City Wastewater Treatment Plant (J.B. Gifford WWTP) has operated their Disinfection Process (Chlorination & Sulfonation Systems) without an incident since the previous RMP submission. This successful operating record is due to the WWTP's commitment to effective management of the RMP elements. RMP elements are assigned to skilled and knowledgeable WWTP personnel who have the overall responsibility to manage their program elements. 68.155(b) Stationary Source and the Substance Handled



The Sanitary District of Michigan City WWTP operates a 15-MGD municipal wastewater treatment plant in the City of Michigan City, Indiana. The Wastewater Treatment Plant uses an aqueous solution of chlorine to provide disinfection of the treated wastewater.  Dechlorination (Sulfonation) is accomplished with an aqueous solution of sulfur dioxide that reacts with chlorine residuals including mono- and dichloramine before the treated wastewater is discharged through NPDES permitted outfalls into Trail Creek. 

The Disinfection Process is located within the perimeter fence line of the wastewater treatment plant site. A physical security protection system including access controls are in place to prev

ent unauthorized personnel from entering the Disinfection Process.  The WWTP maintains chlorine and sulfur dioxide   leak detection devices within the Disinfection Process including the Gas Storage Room, Effluent Disinfection Room and the Storm Basin Disinfection Room. There are audible and visual alarms for chlorine and sulfur dioxide in the facility. The Disinfection Process stores chlorine (Cl2) and sulfur dioxide (SO2) at the Gas Storage Room in 1-ton containers. 

The Effluent Disinfection System and the Storm Basin Disinfection System are systems whereby chlorine and sulfur dioxide gas are fed through systems called a Chlorinator and Sulfonator. A vacuum is created by the site's non-potable water feed system which draws chlorine and sulfur dioxide gas through the Chlorinator and Sulfonator respectively at an amount preset by designated, qualified WWTP personnel. This system provides an excellent active mitigation measure that greatly minimizes the risk of a reportable release to the environment. If a chlorine or sulfur dioxide gas leak occurs anywhere in the system beyond the regulator that is attached to the 1-ton container in the Gas Storage Room, then the vacuum is lost and the regulator automatically shuts-off gas flow at the container. Also, the regulator automatically shut-off gas flow at the container, if the non-potable water source is removed from the process.  

 

The inventory of chlorine and sulfur dioxide fluctuates throughout the year. The Sanitary District's "Disinfection Season" typically begins around the end of February and ends around the first part of December. During this time period, normal inventory in the Gas Storage Room is six (6) 1-ton chlorine containers and five (5) 1-ton sulfur dioxide containers. During the "Disinfection Season", two (2) chlorine containers and two (2) sulfur dioxide containers are feeding gas to the Effluent Disinfection System. Also, one (1) chlorine container and one (1) sulfur dioxide container are feeding g

as to the Storm Water Disinfection System. During the period between early December and late February, the inventory is reduced to only two (2) sulfur dioxide containers and two (2) chlorine containers in the Gas Storage Room. One of the two chlorine containers and one of the two sulfur dioxide containers are connected to their respective gas feed system. Gas inventories on site are carefully managed by operations, maintenance and purchasing. The maximum inventory in the Gas Storage Room is seven (7) 1-ton containers of chlorine and the maximum inventory for sulfur dioxide is six (6) 1-ton containers, but this would rarely occur. 



68.155(d) Accidental Release Prevention Program



The Prevention Program required for compliance with 40 CFR Part 68 for Program 3 processes aligns with the prevention program required under OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119-Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals. Sanitary District management aligned its Disinfection Process Prevention Program with Indiana OSHA PSM regulatory requirements in 2010. The Sanitary District's WWTP operations and maintenance employees are actively involved in the evaluation, review and updates of their prevention programs and safety-related procedures. WWTP operations and maintenance personnel along with subject matter specialists were actively involved in the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) completed on September 2, 2016. 



68.155(e) Five-year Accident History



The chlorination and dechlorination facility has been in place since 1955. No accidents, as described under 40 CFR 68.42(a), have occurred at this facility since the last RMP submission on November 21, 2011. 



68.155(f) Emergency Response Program



The Sanitary District of Michigan City has implemented an Emergency Action Plan in accordance with OSHA 29 CFR 1910.38. Furthermore, the facility is included in the La Porte County Community Emergency Response Plan. If a chemical release occurs in the Disinfection Process, employees are expected t

o follow the Emergency Action Plan including quick notification of the La Porte County 911 Dispatch Center. Normally, Michigan City Fire Department would be first on-scene and assume command including initiation of any community emergency evacuation measures. All response agencies and resources follow FEMA's National Incident Management System Incident Command System protocols and guidelines. WWTP personnel assist responders by providing their technical knowledge of Disinfection Process operations.

  

An emergency response table top exercise was completed on Oct. 21, 2016 with a scenario involving the Disinfection Process. Exercise participants included Sanitary District operations, maintenance and management personnel, Michigan City Fire Department, Michigan City Police Department, La Porte Co. HazMat Director and La Porte Co. Emergency Medical Services.  Also, the Sanitary District's chlorine and sulfur dioxide supplier participated since they provide technical support as an area Chlorine Institute CHLOREP responder.    



68.155(g) Safety Improvements



Suggestions for safety improvement are encouraged and evaluated through our employee participation programs and activities.  Improvements made in response to suggestions from our employees, contractors or learnings from other WWTP sites are routinely considered. Periodic PSM and RMP audits are reviewed by management and action items are tracked to completion. Recommendations for the Disinfection Process are carefully evaluated and documented in accordance with PSM and RMP regulatory requirements. The Contractor Safety Procedure has been significantly improved with additional requirements developed for contractor selection and site orientation. 



Conclusion



As part of the Sanitary District of Michigan City (J.B. Gifford) Wastewater Treatment Plant's commitment to safety and respect for the hazards associated with the handling and storing of chlorine and sulfur dioxide, WWTP personnel enthusiastically striv
e to find and implement opportunities to reduce the risk associated with the use of these chemicals while maintaining effluent water quality and protection of the environment.
